newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks ends down on Dow plunge.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks ends down on Dow plunge.

text.p: The Australian share market ended on Friday with its third consecutive fall in response to the overnight plunge on Wall Street, but investors regained some confidence in the afternoon session.
At the close, the All Ordinaries index was 23.1 points or almost one percent lower at 2,316.5.
December share index futures were down 39 points at 2,305, widening its discount to the underlying index to 11.5 points.
Brokers said the market is still worried about Wall Street as the S&P Globex March contract was about seven points off, which represents one percent off the Dow if it flows through.
"It was a bit of a panic open with the S&P off heavily, that is what really scared our market," said Greg Matthews, executive director of Australian equities at Mercantile Mutual.

"The market is still worried what is going on in the States," Matthews said. The Dow ended nearly 100 points lower on Thursday. The All Ordinaries briefly dipped under 2300 in early trade, just off the support level of 2295.

Matthews said Australian shares recovered ground in the afternoon as the S&P500 March Globex contract regained some earlier losses and received some confidence from the bond market with U.S. treasuries edging higher in Asian trade.
Losses were right across the board with only the food and retail sectors finding some strength.
The media and banking sectors had the largest falls among the industrials. New Cap Reinsurance Corp made a healthy debut, closing 16 cents above its A$2.53 issue price.
Falls outnumbered rises by a ratio of about three to one, while about a quarter of stocks traded remained steady.
Derivatives trade picked on Thusday's trade, but was still seen as fairly average trading. Total options traded 45,869 (32,788), while turnover in December SPI contracts totalled 13,638 (7,284).

In other local markets, Australian bonds had a calmer session after aggressive price swings of the past week. Trade was largely concentrated on bond futures roll over to March ahead of Monday's expire of December positions.
By 5.10 p.m. (0610 GMT), 10 year T-bonds were yielding 7.43 percent, up from Thursday's 7.39 percent.

The Australia dollar nudged back into neutral territory at a thin midsession as Japanese buying helped overcome an early wobble. At 5.10 p.m. (0610 GMT), the Australian dollar was quoted at US$.7926/31.
